body: KAVAKOS--Neil. On November 13th, 2006 of Forest Hills, New York, formal founder and President of Avia Tours Inc. body: When Emmanuel Ko broke the news to his girlfriend that he had decided to become a priest, he clutched a rosary in his right pocket for resolve as she wept. ''It's not like I didn't like her anymore,'' he said. ''I'm doing this because I love him more.'' Mr. Ko, 22, is one of four young men from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn who decided to
title: A Fraternity of Faith, Dwindling but Resolute

body: MICHEL--George W., 83, passed away at the Hope Hospice House in Bonita Springs, Florida on August 30, 2006. He was preceded in death by his parents, William and Vasiliki, brother, Alfred, and sisters, Marie Costas and Aphrodite Fordes, as well as his late wife, Helen Manning Michel. He is survived by his loving wife, Gloria PumroyMichel, step-son
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MICHEL, GEORGE W.

body: A 73-year-old Brooklyn man was found shot to death at his home last night, the police said. The man, Octavius Gill, had been shot once in the back at the two-story wood-frame house in the Cypress Hills area that he shared with his son, Octavius Gill Jr. Investigators said there was no sign of forced entry. The man's body was discovered shortly
title: Man, 73, Shot Dead in Brooklyn

body: An 11-year-old boy was hit by a car and badly injured while crossing a Brooklyn street around 6 p.m. yesterday, the police said. The accident took place near Liberty and North Conduit Avenues in the City Line neighborhood. Witnesses said the boy was crossing the street with his bicycle, accompanied by another boy when he was hit. ''I heard a noise
title: A Boy, 11, Is Struck by a Car in Brooklyn

author: E-mail: peappl@nytimes.com
body: SOME of the voices are so direct they take your breath away. ''I'm poor, but when my lights go out, my soul still soars,'' writes Felton Williamson of Brooklyn, a distant planet from the leafy reaches of northern Westchester, where suburbia turns to exurbia. Some seem like variations on a common theme seen from a different direction. ''And our
title: Our Towns; Worlds Apart, But Bound In Softcover

body: Fossils in the Walls Q. My children and I love fossils. Lately I've heard that there are some great-looking ones in Manhattan building walls and pillars. Can you recommend any buildings for fossil viewing? A. Sidney Horenstein, geologist and environmental educator emeritus at the American Museum of Natural History, recommended these: The
title: F. Y. I.

body: There are few things more confusing than a young girl's coffin. It feels like a betrayal, or a broken promise. You see it, but it makes no sense. That was the prevailing sentiment yesterday at Nixzmary Brown's funeral, a warm Mass in a cold church on the Lower East Side. Uniformed marines carried the coffin in and carried it out again, but no one
title: Tears Mix With Rain for a Last Goodbye to a Lost Child

body: A grand jury charged the mother and stepfather of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown with murder yesterday, detailing accusations that the mother had not only allowed a pattern of violent abuse that ended in the girl's death, but also participated in it. That pattern approached its climax on Jan. 10 as Nixzmary's siblings were compelled to accuse her of
title: Murder Charges Detail Torture of 7-Year-Old
